message: The official Twiter client is getting more and more bloated and crashier with each update it seems. I hope the duo at Tapbots manage to make a nice feature rich but fast client like what Tweetie (RIP) once was.
Echofon is the best in my opinion and has Alot of nice features

I'm worried about Twitter's stance on third party apps. The official app is no where near the best right now. I've tried almost every app out there and the best right now is TweetLogix. Bad name, great app. It's fast, you can file in the gaps, and has one tap links and options.
Echofon made me like twitter. I'll keep using that one.
I currently use tweetlogix. I do like Echofon but it won't fill in the gaps for tweets that you've missed.

I actually really like the official twitter client.  I think it's pretty lightweight and well designed.  The only feature I still miss from echofon is unread syncing between the desktop client and the phone app.
Twitter recently told devs to quit replicating the standard featureset and make new stuff. What that means for Tweetbot, Twitterrific, Echofon et al, who knows.
Check out Tweetlist for iPhone. Perfect alternative

@adamfairhead I think twitter said that since there is Alot of half ass clients out there and it is protecting there brand also echofon has a following so I think they can see that so I think it is safe for now but I see where twitter comes from they don't want the same app over and over again

@italiano40 You're likely right. Echofon and Twitterrific, I'm thinking. I'd imagine they would at this point seriously consider building in a USP to each of their respective apps to differentiate from the official client. A USP that doesn't equate to drastically change the user experience and alienate new users, much like Twitter fears. I guess we'll see!
@italiano40  i like Alots. http://hyperboleandahalf.blogspot.com/2010/04/alot-is-better-than-you-at-everything.html
Better

@tweakskys I'm in the same boat. I loved Tweetie, and I still think the official Twitter app is the best, but it has it's quirks. On the other hand, I like every app from Tapbots, so I'm looking forward to seeing what they come up with.
@jenali What do you mean it won't fill the gaps?

I've been using Echofon for quite a while now and consider it the best. They have way more support for in-app photo viewing than the official iPhone client (instagram, flickr, etc.), and they recently added inline thumbnails for photos—something I didn't realize was so cool until I had it in my timeline.
I know a lot of people love the official app (pre dickbar), but I haven't heard anyone explain why they like it better than Echofon.

@park if you don't check the app for 24 hours, it will only update some of the tweets you missed. Some apps show a gap of tweets you missed with the ability to fill in the missing tweets. The best app at doing this is TweetLogix. The official Twitter app does a good job too. I really like Echofon and Twittelator but they don't have this option. I also like apps that have clickable links in the timeline.
Yeah, they sit in the realm of Blizzard, Apple, or Panic where you basically know whatever they come out with it's going to be good
can't wait for Tweetbot
all their apps are great
i love that company alot
Is echofon still restricted to portrait mode until you compose a tweet where u can THEN go landscape?

Since I tweet on 3 different devices (iPhone, iPad, and Mac), I find it extemely useful to use a client that supports Tweet sync which marks tweets in your time line as read on all your devices. So far I know of only a fee clients that support this: Tweetings, Echofon, and to some extent Tweetdeck. I am now using Tweetings on all my devices.
I just switched back to Echofon after a long hiatus with Tweetie. They keep removing features.
@laurentlogan yep only landscape in composing a tweet

@park you can't view all of the tweets in your timeline. A few twitter clients will detect that there's a gap of tweets between when you last opened the app and now. You have an option to tap on load more tweets, fill in the gap or some other phrase that will show the tweets you missed in that span of time. That feature isn't available on Echofon.
CANNOT wait for this. If you guys haven't tried their other apps, check them out now. some of the best synergy between design and function that you'll find on iOS.
Not very revealing screenshot of Tweetbot via @gruber: http://twitpic.com/4cmpla
Looks like a cross between Weightbot and Twitterrific, don't you think?
@justinluey Ah, I see. I've never gone more than a couple hours without checking Echofon, let alone 24 hours. I agree, though, they should have that feature.
This is the first I've heard of Tweetbot, but I think I will definitely be trying it out. True Weight is better than Weightbot, but I love their style anyway.
I just hope it is fast.
Looks like app store already have an app named Tweetbot. Is it authentic?
@anildigital It's not an app from Tapbots in any case. @joshd I hope so too.

Twitter for iPhone has really been acting up the last week. I've had to completely re-install it twice this week and crashes at least once every 3 days. I have 4 accounts for the record, I don't know if that may have something to do with it.
@tweakskys try echofon is it is really good, also you may need to buy there pro version for more accounts idk but it is really good and always works for me
I agree, Echofon is key! it allows syncing between desktops and mobile devices.
Yep, but I don't want to leave Twitterrific ^^

Tweetbot has now been released. It's already on the Japanese App Store, just need it to be available on the US Store now. Am most definitely interested to see how it holds up in comparison to the official Twitter app.
I am waiting for it. Can someone tell how many hours are remaining for it to be launched on US Store?
I cant download boxcar :S. And why doest push notifications for tweetbot has to work via boxcar??
It's in the US store
@danmon they probably noticed how fast boxcar is at push and i boxcar is a must have app for the IOS
I'm in love
@danmon I guess they've decided to add push at some later date. Launch now, iterate later.

It is awesome! The related tweets is something I've been wanting for a long time. Though I wish they could highlight somehow usernames, links and hashtags in the timeline. Also have a small indication that a tweet is a reply (has conversation), so I don't have to guess (like TweetList).
What will be the differance betweek tweetbot and the already existing official twitter app.  I thought twitter banned all 3rd party twitter apps?
Thank you guys!
@undefined They didn't ban 3rd party twitter apps.
Woot... actually they implemented all I've said before. The only thing I miss is having the tweet as title when adding to Read It Later. Everything else rules :)
I like Tweetbot, except for the retweet bars that interrupt the stream.

Twitter grandfathered all existing third party apps, but they've pretty much declared war on any new apps and will probably limit further development of current apps at some point. See here: http://arst.ch/ojy
@TSJ I agree. Very much against the original spirit behind Twitter. I guess it's "lets be happy and nice and let everyone come and build for us and then lock it down hard".
@gamoe It's a ridiculous stance by Twitter. It would be like Facebook blocking every browser apart from IE, or something like that.
Maybe this is an opportunity for services like convore to grab more users and developers! more convore apps here we come!
@gamoe It's not unlike their decision to block twitlonger, especially given that their Mac app had support for twitlonger.

I like Tweetbot a lot. Especially the related tweets and the ability to set your location to a specific point of interest. But only 3 minor features/tweaks I wish it had.  1) Ability to jump directly to an @ user name. 2) currently not all of the people you follow are loaded so if you try to search for a name in your followers list it may not show up if it is too far down the list. 3) ability for local search.  One of the things I like about the official twitter iphone app was the ability to see tweets around you or at in a geographic location.
